title: 103_hr3060
content: The Act may be cited as the "Electronic Funds Transfer Federal Salary Act" and aims to ensure safe, economical, and effective payroll administration. The "Electronic Funds Transfer Federal Salary Act" amends Section 3332 of title 31, United States Code, defining financial organizations and authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to require electronic transfers for employee pay if deemed practical and beneficial. The "Electronic Funds Transfer Federal Salary Act" amends Section 3332 of title 31, United States Code to require electronic transfers for employee pay if practical and establishes safeguards for fund control and accounting. Regulations must designate a financial organization to receive payments, with the Secretary prohibiting transfer fees. The Electronic Funds Transfer Federal Salary Act prohibits financial organizations from charging agency employees for handling payments authorized by the Secretary. Employees with annual pay below $20,000 can request exemption. National security exceptions are in place for certain provisions. The Central Intelligence Agency can be exempt from regulations if compliance risks intelligence disclosure or compromises security. Acceptance of payment by a financial organization from the US constitutes full acquittance. Payments to individuals can be made via electronic fund transfers upon request to the Secretary. Upon request, payments to individuals can be made via electronic fund transfers, as stated in the written request to the Secretary. Amendments to Section 3332 of title 31, United States Code, include redesignating subsection (f) as subsection (e) and clarifying payment procedures.
